preamble: In this section, we will ask you about preprocessing decisions, such as analysis software, off-line filtering, re-referencing, artefact removal, epoching and baseline.
question: Did you use the same software for all pre-processing steps?
details: Preprocessing steps are fitlering, downsampling, re-referencing, artifact removal, epoching and baseline correction, and other up to the point of data collection
choices: preset:boolean

question: Which software did you use?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
Did you use an automated pre-processing pipeline which executes more than artifact removal decisions?
details: For example, this automated pipeline may also include filtering, baseline correction, or re-referencing.
choices: preset:boolean

question: Which automated pre-processing pipeline did you use?
choices: PREP (Bigdely-Shamlo et al., 2015) | HAPPE (Gabard-Durnam et al., 2018) | HAPPE+ER (Monachino et al., 2021) | EPOS (Rodrigues et al., 2021) | other

question: Automated pre-processing pipeline you used other than listed
Reference for the automated pre-processing pipeline you applied.
Version of the automated pre-processing pipeline, if applicable
Describe parameters and settings you used to run this automated pipeline, if applicable.
Did you apply any of the following offline (digital) filters?
details: This does not include filtering within automated pipelines, if you had applied any.
choices: high pass | low pass | notch | none

question: Which software do you use for implementing offline filters on EEG data?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
What kind of high-pass filter did you use?
choices: preset:filter

question: What was the length/order of the high-pass filter?
Type of high-pass filter cut-off
choices: half-power | half-amplitude

question: Specify the offline high-pass filter cut-off.
Specify the offline high-pass filter roll off.
What is the attenuation achieved in the stopband after high-pass filtering?
What was the direction of the high-pass filter?
choices: forwards | backwards | forwards and backwards

question: What kind of low-pass filter did you use?
choices: preset:filter

question: What was the length/order of the low-pass filter?
Type of high-pass filter cut-off
choices: half-power | half-amplitude

question: Specify the offline low-pass filter cut-off.
Specify the offline low-pass filter roll off.
What is the attenuation achieved in the stopband after low-pass filtering?
What was the direction of the low-pass filter?
choices: forwards | backwards | forwards and backwards

question: What notch filter have you applied after the recording?
choices: 50 Hz | 60 Hz | other

question: Describe the stopband frequency of the notch filter you applied
Did you downsample your data?
choices: preset:boolean

question: What software did you use for downsampling?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected and software name and version if "other" was selected.
If yes, what was your new sampling frequency?
Did you re-reference offline?
details: This does not include re-referencing within automated pipelines, if you had applied any.
choices: preset:boolean

question: Which analysis software do you use for re-referencing on EEG data?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
What was the new reference?
How many artifact elimination steps did you have?
details: This section refers to artifact removal (correction, rejection) methods other than elimating participants from the sample, which should be described in the Experimental design and sample section. This section should not include artifact removal within automated pipelines already described above.

question: What action did you take regarding artifacts in step 1?
choices: reject bad trial or bad data segment | correct by subtraction (blinks, EKG etc.) | reject channels | interpolate channels | multi-step automated approach (e.g., FASTER)

question: What software did you use for artifact removal in step 1?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected and software name and version if "other" was selected.
Did you reject trials or segments of continuous data in step 1?
choices: trials | data segments

question: How did you define your artifacts in step 1?
choices: visual inspection | pre-set numerical criterion/function | other

question: Which artifacts did you remove using visual inspection in step 1?
choices: blinks | saccades | other occular | cardiac | motion and other EMG noise | alpha waves | line noise | other

question: Which other artifacts did you remove visually?
Describe your numerical criterion/function and provide numerical threshold(s) in step 1.
Describe your method of artifact rejection other than visual inspection or numerical criterion/function. Make sure that there is enough detail for a replication attempt.
Which general method of artifact correction did you use in step 1?
choices: regression-based approach (e.g., Gratton et al., 1983, Elbert et al., 1985) | spatial-filter-based approach (e.g., Dale, 1994) | ICA-based approaches | wavelet-based | wavelet-enhanced ICA (e.g., Khushaba et al, 2013) | multiple-source-analysis-based approaches (e.g., MSEC by Berg & Scherg, 1994) | other

question: Reference to the artifact correction algorithm used in step 1
Describe artifact correction parameters in detail sufficient for replication.
details: For example, provide numerical parameters, options selected, or describe decision-making process as closely as possible if manual, visual-inspection based decisions were involved.

question: From which data did you eliminate bad channels in step 1?
choices: from individual trials | from segments of continuous data | from the entire recording

question: List of channels eliminated in step 1, separated by a semicolon and a space.
What was the criterion for eliminating bad channels in step 1?
choices: visual inspection | pre-set numerical criterion/function | other

question: Why did you remove bad electrodes in step 1?
choices: excessive line noise | excessive muscle activity | bad contact and other large fluctations in voltage | dead electrode | excessive EMG noise | cardiac activity | other

question: Which other reasons did you have for eliminating bad electrodes visually in step 1?
Describe your numerical criterion/function for eliminating electrodes and provide numerical threshold(s) in step 1.
Describe your method of electrode rejection other than visual inspection or numerical criterion/function. Make sure that there is enough detail for a replication attempt.
How did you select channels for interpolation in step 1?
details: Describe the numerical threshold or function used to define which channels should be interpolated.

question: Describe interpolation function and the settings you used in step 1.
details: Provide appropriate details and settings, as well as a reference, if appropriate.

question: Reference to the automated artifact removal algorithm used in step 1
Describe automated artifact removal parameters in detail sufficient for replication.
details: For example, provide numerical parameters, options selected, or describe decision-making process as closely as possible if manual, visual-inspection based decisions were involved.

question: We are sorry, but this is an early version of the web-app, and it currently includes up to 7 steps of artifact removal decisions due to technical limitations. Describe your remaining decisions in this field as detailed as you can.
Did you epoch data outside of the automated pre-processing pipelines described earlier?
choices: preset:boolean

question: Which analysis software did you use for epoching EEG data?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
What was the epoch beginning relative to a trigger point? For timings after the trigger, use positive numbers. For timings before the trigger, use negative numbers.
What was the event type relative to which epochs were defined?
choices: stimulus onset | response | feedback onset | other

question: If other, what is the event?
What was the epoch end relative to a trigger point? For timings after the trigger, use positive numbers. For timings before the trigger, use negative numbers.
Did you apply baseline correction?
details: This does not include baseline correction within automated pipelines, if you had applied any.
choices: preset:boolean

question: Which analysis software did you use for baseline correction?
choices: preset:meeg_analysis_softwares

question: Specify software version if applicable, script language if "custom script" was selected, and software name and version if "other" was selected.
What was the baseline period beginning relative to a trigger point? For timings after the trigger, use positive numbers. For timings before the trigger, use negative numbers.
What was the baseline period end relative to a trigger point? For timings after the trigger, use positive numbers. For timings before the trigger, use negative numbers.
Which baseline calculation method was used?
choices: subtract mean of the baseline period per condition | other

question: Specify your baseline calculation method other than subtraction of the mean of the baseline.
Describe order of all pre-processing steps described here in a way that allows replication.
